DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term that represents the kind of technique used to give anesthesia.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Agents that are capable of inducing a total or partial loss of sensation, especially tactile sensation and pain. They may act to induce general anesthesia, in which an unconscious state is achieved, or may act locally to induce numbness or lack of sensation at a targeted site. (MeSH)_The act of the dispensing, applying, or tendering of something to another, such as administration of a medicine._A practiced and regimented skill or series of actions.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: (an-es-THET-iks) Substances that cause loss of feeling or awareness. Local anesthetics cause loss of feeling in a part of the body. General anesthetics put the person to sleep.

Concepts.definition: A pharmacological agent that acts in a reversible fashion and can be applied either locally or systemically to cause a partial or total loss of sensation and pain or to induce unconsciousness.

Property.preferredDefinition: The act of administration.:A practiced and regimented skill or series of actions.

Concepts.definition: The act of the dispensing, applying, or tendering of something to another, such as administration of a medicine.
A practiced and regimented skill or series of actions.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for newborn exam form per request by R.Srivastava. mc 3/1/13

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Treatment with a pharmacological substance that produces a loss of feeling._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A procedure in which a pharmaceutical agent is administered into the subarachnoid space, producing a loss of sensation at and below the level of the block.

Concepts.definition: A procedure in which a pharmaceutical agent is administered into the subarachnoid space, producing a loss of sensation at and below the level of the block.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.: The administration of pharmaceutical agents intended to produce loss of sensation in a particular anatomical region.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
The administration of pharmaceutical agents intended to produce loss of sensation in a particular anatomical region.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Actions that render a patient unconscious for the purpose of performing a diagnostic or interventional procedure.

Concepts.definition: Actions that render a patient unconscious for the purpose of performing a diagnostic or interventional procedure.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The temporary suppression of sensation at a specific region of the body by pharmacological intervention. This type of anesthesia does not induce unconsciousness in the patient.

Concepts.definition: The temporary suppression of sensation at a specific region of the body by pharmacological intervention. This type of anesthesia does not induce unconsciousness in the patient.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Epidural Route of Administration Regional Anesthesia Procedure

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Epidural Route of Administration Regional Anesthesia Procedure
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Administration upon or over the dura mater.: The administration of pharmaceutical agents intended to produce loss of sensation in a particular anatomical region.

Concepts.definition: Administration of the drug in the epidural space, usually at the lumbar level of the spine. The drug must initially cross the dura mater before exerting its effect on the nervous system components. The drug is also subject to uptake into the rich epidural plexus of veins. Uptake and distribution after epidural administration resembles that seen after intramuscular injection. The portion of drug that is not taken into the vascular compartment is available to cross the dura. Hydrophilicity is a major component in the pharmacokinetics of drug transfer into the subdural space.
The administration of pharmaceutical agents intended to produce loss of sensation in a particular anatomical region.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The administration of pharmaceutical agents intended to produce loss of sensation in a particular anatomical region.

Concepts.definition: The administration of pharmaceutical agents intended to produce loss of sensation in a particular anatomical region.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: (an-es-THEE-zha) Loss of feeling or awareness.  Local anesthetics cause loss of feeling in a part of the body.  general anesthetics put the person to sleep.:Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

Concepts.definition: Treatment with a pharmacological substance that produces a loss of feeling.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
